close_symbols: any functions called by SHA1CircularShift (and their definitions)
integer typedefs used (e.g. uint32_t / stdint.h typedefs)
explanation:
SHA1CircularShift: This function is invoked inside every for-loop body. MISRA requires that the behaviour of the for-loop body (including called functions) has no persistent side-effects that affect loop control. To determine compliance you must inspect the full prototype and implementation of SHA1CircularShift to ensure it does not modify the loop counter 'i', any objects used in the loop clauses, or any global/volatile state that could act as a loop-control flag.

struct SHA1Context: The loops reference members of the context (message_block, intermediate_hash). You need the struct definition to know the types and qualifiers (e.g. whether any members are volatile, or alias to objects modified elsewhere) and to confirm that no member used in the loop clauses is modified in the loop body or by callees (which would breach the MISRA restriction on using objects modified in the loop body in the loop condition).

Any functions called by SHA1CircularShift (and their definitions): If SHA1CircularShift itself calls other functions, those callees also form part of the loop body behaviour. MISRA requires inspecting the whole call chain for persistent side-effects or modifications to loop counters/objects used in loop clauses.

Integer typedefs used (e.g. uint32_t): Knowing the exact integer types and their signed/unsigned/width properties is necessary to reason about expressions in the loop body and whether any operations could inadvertently modify loop control objects (for example via aliasing or undefined behaviour).
